The Board has advocated for international measures to forestall the development of   highly volatile funding structures outside the regulated sector.  Consistent with this position, we   will be developing a regulation that would establish minimum haircuts for securities financing   transactions (SFTs) on a market-wide basis, rather than just for specific classes of market   participants.  SFTs include repo, reverse repo, securities lending and borrowing, and securities   margin lending--transactions that are the lifeblood of many kinds of shadow banks.  SFTs are a   key component of the healthy functioning of the securities market.  But, in the absence of   sensible regulation, they also carry the potential for prompting the fire sale dynamic described   earlier.  While the haircuts and other conditions associated with SFTs today are considerably   more conservative than during the period leading up to the crisis, there is good reason to believe   that this conservatism could be eroded as economic conditions continue to improve and credit   growth accelerates.    A system of numerical haircut floors for SFTs would require any entity that wants to   borrow against a security to post a minimum amount of excess margin to its lender, with the   amount varying depending on the asset class of the collateral.  Like the minimum margin   requirements that U.S. regulators have imposed on derivatives contracts, numerical floors for   SFT haircuts would serve as a mechanism for limiting the build-up of leverage in the financial   system.  They could also mitigate the risk to financial stability posed by pro-cyclical margin calls   during times of financial stress, since putting a regulatory floor under SFT haircuts during good   times would reduce the amount by which they would increase during periods of stress.
